abstract.para: &slereg; (&slea;) allows to upgrade an existing system to the new version, for example, going from &slea; 12 SP4 to the latest &slea; &product-ga; service pack. No new installation is needed. Existing data, such as home and data directories and system configuration, is kept intact. You can update from a local CD or DVD drive or from a central network installation source.
This chapter explains how to manually upgrade your &sle; system, be it by DVD, network, an automated process, or &susemgr;.

sect1.title: Supported Upgrade Paths to &slea; &productnumber;
sect1.para: Before you perform any migration, read .

important.title: Cross-architecture Upgrades Are Not Supported
important.para: Cross-architecture upgrades, such as upgrading from a 32-bit version of &productname; to the 64-bit version, or upgrading from big endian to little endian are not supported!
Specifically, &slea; 11 on &ppc; (big endian) to &slea; &productnumber; on &ppc; (new: little endian!) is not supported.
Also, since &sle; &product-ga; is 64-bit only, upgrades from any 32-bit &sle; 11 systems to &sle; &product-ga; and later are not supported.
To make a cross-architecture upgrade, you need to perform a new installation.

note.title: Skipping Service Packs
note.para: The easiest upgrade path is consecutively installing all service packs. For the &sle; 15 product line (GA and the subsequent service packs) it is also supported to skip one service pack when upgrading. For example, upgrading from &slea; 15 GA to 15 SP2 or from &slea; 15 SP1 to 15 SP3 is supported.
Skipping service packs on &sled; is not supported. You need to consecutively install all service packs.

note.title: Upgrading Major Releases
note.para: We recommend to do a fresh install when upgrading to a new Major Release, for example from &sle; 12 to &sle; 15.

listitem.para: There is no supported direct migration path to &sle; &productnumber;. We recommend a fresh installation in this case.

varlistentry.term: Upgrading from &sle; 11 GA / SP1 / SP2 / SP3

listitem.para: If you cannot do a fresh install, first upgrade your installed &slea; 11 Service Pack to &slea; 11 SP4. These steps are described in the &sle; 11 Deployment Guide.
Upgrading from &slea; 11 SP4 is only supported via an offline upgrade. Refer to for details.
A direct upgrade from &slea; 12 GA / SP1 / SP2 to &slea; &productnumber; is not supported. You need to upgrade to &slea; 12 SP3 first.
Upgrading from &sle; 12 SP3 is only supported via an offline upgrade. Refer to for details.
Migrating from &opensuse; Leap 15 is supported. See . Only the server installation of Leap is supported for migration.
See for instructions on upgrading &slea; guests in public clouds.
Upgrading from &sle; 12 SP2 and any older version is not supported.
Upgrading from &sle; 12 SP3 is only supported via an offline upgrade. Refer to for details.

sect1.title: Online and Offline Upgrade
sect1.para: &suse; supports two different upgrade and migration methods. For more information about the terminology, see . The methods are:

listitem.para: Upgrades that are executed from the running operating system itself (system up and running state). Examples: online update with Zypper or &yast;, connected through &scc; or &rmtool; (&rmt;), Salt Policy via &susemgr;.
When migrating between Service Packs of the same major release, we suggest following or .

Upgrading offline implies that the operating system to be upgraded is not running (system down state). Instead, the installer for the target operating system is booted (for example, from the installation media, via network or via local boot loader), and performs the upgrade.
